Big Orn

I have seen many posts here about quality of life, but not what that term means, or the definition of it.
 
 I would think that "quality of life" would have many definitions.
 
 What would yours be?
 
 When this thread has run its course maybe we can come up with some meaning and refer to it each time.
jim's trucking

I have seen many posts here about quality of life, but not what that term means, or the definition of it.
 
 I would think that "quality of life" would have many definitions.
 
 What would yours be?
 
 When this thread has run its course maybe we can come up with some meaning and refer to it each time.

 
 A quality existence would have high degrees of:
 
 healthy populations
 the ability to obtain necessities
 the ability to obtain luxuries
 the ability to live unharmed by others
 the ability to create new choices for consumption
 the ability to travel freely and witness nature
 the ability to listen to and create music

 I agree with Jim on this one but you have to add Less government, No war, No Clowns telling society how to live, Getting more people to smile. That is a quality that we used to have in the old days and we need them again. This country needs to get a sence of humor.

I agree with Jim on this one but you have to add Less government, No war, No Clowns telling society how to live, Getting more people to smile. That is a quality that we used to have in the old days and we need them again. This country needs to get a sence of humor.

 
 You can basically sum this up in one word. Freeeeeeeeeeeeeeeedom!
Alucard

I don't know. I think quality of life depends on how happy you are no matter the circumstances. For example, if I was blissfully ignorant living on a farm somewhere far away from society, I would say I have a good quality of life. Or if I was pumped full of pills that leave me in a stuporous euphoria, and lying on some hospital bed, I could say I have a good "quality of life". So, whatever brings a person closer to a state of happiness would support a positive quality of life and whatever would prevent that state or draw a person away from it is in opposition to a positive quality of life.
Eddie

When talking about the quality of the life of an individual, I think you need to understand that particular individuals preferences and beliefs. But if we are talking about some form of "objective" quality of life in terms of populations, I think the Human Development Report serves a good purpose. Its administered by UN and tries to measure the "well-being" of the populace in different nations by looking at several indexes that weighs a number of factors
 
 HDI (Human Development Index)
 life expectancy, 
 education attainment 
 standard of living (GDP/capita), 
 
 HPI (Human Poverty Index)
 Infant mortality, 
 Availability to forms of comunications 
 Standard of living (an economic overview)
 Social inclussion (measures of inclusion and exclusion from society)
 
 GDI (Gender Development Index)
 Measures the statistical differences between men and women in regards of:
 life expectancy 
 educational attainment 
 income
 
 GEM (Gender Empowerment Index)
 Measures the statistical differences between men and women in regards of:
 economic participation and decision-making 
 political participation and decision-making 
 power over economic resources 
 
 Sometimes HDI is used alone as an indicator of "well-being" but I would argue that at least the HPI and one of the gender indexes serves an important purpose.
Big Orn

Or if I was pumped full of pills that leave me in a stuporous euphoria, and lying on some hospital bed, I could say I have a good "quality of life". So, whatever brings a person closer to a state of happiness would support a positive quality of life and whatever would prevent that state or draw a person away from it is in opposition to a positive quality of life.

 I think you have a good point, Alucard. There definitely is a negative quality of life, whether we see it as such or not.
 Example: Patricia Hearst's mental state while in the "security" of her captors after being "brainwashed".
 
 What about peace of mind? If we can control our own minds, then surely we will be able to attain peace of mind. But, it seems, we are prisoners if we cannot. Inner peace of Nirvana, anyone?
 

 by Henry David Thoreau
 The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation.

 There is a lot of truth in that.
 
 Any more? I am taking notes from each one. Let’s keep it simple.
Anastasia

I think quality of life might have something to do with how you set your goals.. I have always believed in setting goals for myself but with some limits. I think a lot of people reach to high and never attain what they want thus always wanting for more... and maybe never having the quality of life they had in mind.
 I think I have quality in my life, I have beautiful children, great husband, great job. I am not wealthy but I am not starving. I have what I need..
 I set my goals and I achieve them one by one.
 I always get what I want eventually.... 
 Peace of mind is only up to you, you are the only one that can change that. Be realistic in your visions and I think you will feel much better about what you have...spiritually
Big Orn

Jim’s trucking states QOL as abilities to establish comforts. Good
 
 Sglaine states that it is freedom from governmental oppression. Good
 
 AMD4EVER states that it is indeed complete freedom. Good
 
 Alucard believes that it is your (our) state of mind. Good
 
 Eddie credits it to the health of a nation. Good
 
 Anastasia believes that it stems from how we align our goals with how we are physically and spiritually Good
 
 These are great examples of how we look at life and how we place ourselves in it.
 
 Great job! I appreciate your feedback.
 
 Anyone else?
King Triton

I think quality of life as it would be defined by todays terms,would have more to do with social and economic issuses,but also on the other hand,with the advances we are seeing daily in the science field,I hope to see quality of life improve within my lifetime by the elimination of birth defects such as downs syndrome,M.S.etc.
ChapaquidickTed

It's beautiful to be able to live in a country where people can complain about quality of life. Personally I think everyone should be entitled to flat screen tvs like these prisoners. Why stop there? Why should some people have to drive 7-year-old cars? 3 year limit on age of car, that's quality of life. I also think rich people should have to give most of their money to other people. Heck with capitalism, communism is the way to go, equal share for everyone. Of course I'm being sarcastic. I think people in this country have begun to get their 'needs' confused with their 'wants.' Believe it or not, there is a difference. Does someone on foodstamps taking money from the taxpayers of the state 'need' ring pops and skittles? I'm sick of this quality of life PC BS. That's why I goto Scarborough Country, no passport required and no PC Police.
Alucard

Heck with capitalism, communism is the way to go, equal share for everyone. Of course I'm being sarcastic. I think people in this country have begun to get their 'needs' confused with their 'wants.' Believe it or not, there is a difference. Does someone on foodstamps taking money from the taxpayers of the state 'need' ring pops and skittles? I'm sick of this quality of life PC BS. That's why I goto Scarborough Country, no passport required and no PC Police.

 
 Ok, lets try to sort out your arguments. 
 
 First you complain that no one living in this country should even try to define or talk about quality of life because we have it so good, then you toot capitalism's horn. So do you appreciate the benefits of America's prosperous economy enough to scold those who enjoy it? 
 
 Then you jump the fence again and make an argument that poor people (or in PC demon language - lower in the economic strata) don't "need" to buy candy and things that make them happy with the foodstamps given to them by the government. Would you like the government to regulate what these people buy with their foodstamps? How about only bread, since most people only "need" bread to survive. Imagine the breadlines. Oh wait, we're back in Communist Russia. Didn't you previously make a witty quip about how Communism pales in comparison to capitalism? Choose a side please.
 
 And finally, I'm glad you enjoy Scarborough Country so much. If it's anything like Marlborough Country or Flavor Country (which is located somewhere on the border of Marlborough Country) it's probably smooth, mild and right wing Republican. Is it anything like being in the No-Spin Zone? I hope he isn't shaping your ideaology because, although I dislike many of the PCness of the previous few years, quality of life is a basic human quality that is worth discussing and has come up in more debates than one can name.
 
 PS: That show might garner more viewers if it was called Scarborough Fair, and instead of a television show, it was a song by Simon & Garfunkle.

I can totally understand listing material conditions as important criteria of a quality life, but I think life is of the highest quality only if it is filled with meaning. A hard, meaningful life seems higher quality to me than a comfortable, meaningless one.
valet_dave

I think we could be a little less specific on what constitutes "quality of life". From my perspective, quality it is simply a measure of motivation to live, whatever that may entail.
 
 Once you have lost your motivation to live, then you obviously have no quality of life.
 
 It's difficult making a definition that needs to accomodate the full spectrum, from people on their death bed, to those of good health who simply want more.
